newsitem.title: USA: NFL AMERICAN FOOTBALL-COWBOYS FINE SWITZER $75,000 FOR GUN INCIDENT.
newsitem.headline: NFL AMERICAN FOOTBALL-COWBOYS FINE SWITZER $75,000 FOR GUN INCIDENT.

text.p: Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones fined his head coach Barry Switzer a whopping $75,000 on Wednesday after Switzer was arrested for carrying a loaded gun through a busy international airport.

Jones, whose efforts to clean up the Cowboys' tarnished image suffered a heavy blow with Switzer's arrest on Monday, said he hoped the fine would send a clear message that the team is changing its ways for good.
"I'm fining Barry Switzer $75,000. Period," Jones told reporters at the Cowboys pre-season training camp in Austin, Texas.

"I hope the actions I am taking will be a reinforcement to our fans and everyone involved that we are working towards a long-term, not a short-term, effort to educate ourselves and help create more awareness of our responsibility," Jones said.

Switzer was arrested at Dallas-fort Worth International Airport on Monday morning when a .38 calibre handgun was found in his carry-on luggage as he walked through a security checkpoint before boarding a plane to Austin.
Switzer apologised for the incident but said he had no idea the gun was in the bag.
He said he hid it in there last Saturday because there were three children visiting his house, and that he forgot to take it out later.
"It's unfortunate, it's embarrassing to me, but I can live with it because I was more concerned about the safety of those children," Switzer said on Monday.
Several Cowboys players rallied behind Switzer but Jones, who has staunchly defended his head coach from criticism in the past, was less understanding.
He said he accepted Switzer's explanation but stressed that the offence was too serious to go unpunished.
"We are accountable and just being sorry and just apologising for an action that was not intentional is not enough," Jones said.
He said the $75,000 would go to a charity organisation that helps the families of Texas police and firefighters who have been killed or seriously injured in the line of duty.
The Cowboys team has won three super Bowl titles in the 1990s but its public image has been battered by a series of sex and drugs scandals involving some of its star players.

Jones recently decided to try to put a stop to the off-the-field problems and has imposed a new code of conduct aimed at keeping his players away from strip clubs and night spots where they are likely to get into trouble.
Switzer, who is in his fourth season as Cowboys head coach, could face charges for the gun incident.

It is a third-degree felony punishable by two to 10 years in jail and a fine of up to $10,000 but, while police are expected to file charges, it is not yet clear whether U.S. or state prosecutors will actually take up the case if they believe it was a genuine accident.

The Texas Department of Public Safety said Switzer was not licensed to carry a gun. Carrying a handgun without a permit is a lesser charge under state law, a crime in theory punishable by as much as a year in jail and a $4,000 fine.
The Cowboys opened their preseason last Sunday with a 34-27 loss to the Oakland Raiders at Texas Stadium.
